title: Newman to Now
desc:
The Newman to Now Project is designed by Memphis Heritage and partially funded by Humanities Tennessee, an independent affiliate of the National Endowment for the Humanities.  It uses the historic photographs taken by Don Newman between the 1940s and 60s and contemporary photographs of the same sites taken by photographer Gary Walpole to explore continuity and change in Memphis' built environment.

This exhibit uses the photographs, along with newspaper articles, interviews, and a virtual walking tour to explore these forces.  Enjoy exploring the Memphis of Don Newman and the Memphis of Now.

title: About Don Newman
desc:
During the 1940’s 50’s and 60’s, Don Newman photographed Memphis, especially the downtown area, using an 8″ x 10″ view camera.

Newman was a native Memphian. Born in 1919, he graduated from Tech High School in 1937 and began working for the commercial and industrial photographer George Haley shortly after graduation. In 1939 Don married Bertha Mae to whom he was married until he passed away in 1994.

Newman worked briefly as a photographer for the Memphis Engraving Company, and then for Frank Hitchings, whom he eventually bought out with Jack Fury after Hitching’s retirement. Many of the photographs in the Newman archive were produced for assignments or jobs, however a large number were made to satisfy his personal curiosity and interests.

The photographs are black and white, and the scenes are familiar to Memphians born after Newman’s time.

The equipment – an 80-pound tripod, 25-pound view camera and 10 film holders, each the size of a large briefcase – would be carried around town. A photographer in 1950 in the middle of a Memphis summer had his work cut out for him.

For more than four decades, a man of great aspirations captured a city with a great ambition. If a picture is worth a thousand words, then Don Newman’s photographs give us a history book’s worth of tales. They are the stories of where people shopped, what they wore, the cars they drove and spaces where they worked, ate and played.

title: Architecture
desc:
The architectural styles chosen by the architects and developers of our early streetscapes speak volumes about the times in which they were built, as well as the people who built them. Architecture is a reflection of the style of the day, the ethos of the day, and the inventions and limitations in building materials and technology of the day. This section of the Newman to Now Digital Exhibit explores various architectural styles found in Memphis, and photographed by Don Newman, and places them in the context of their architectural history.

title: Italinate (1840-1845)
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)

The Italianate architectural style was popular throughout the United States from the 1840s to the 1880s. The style can be identified by flat or low-pitched roofs, widely overhanging eaves supported by decorative brackets, and tall, narrow windows, commonly arched or curved and hooded or crowned on top. Most popular between 1850 and 1870, many of the decorative elements were made of cast iron or press-metal, two building technologies developed during this period.

Inspired by the rambling, asymmetrical character of Italian farmhouses, the largely residential style was part of the Picturesque/Romantic Movement as a reaction to the formal classical ideas of the earlier Federal and Greek Revival styles. Rather than imposing a rigid, classical order, the movement granted more freedom in architectural expression and complemented a building’s natural setting. 

Many of Memphis’ earliest surviving buildings are of the Italianate style, most notably the remaining townhouses and commercial block buildings found throughout Downtown that were built between the late 1840s and early 1880s. It wasn’t until the 1840s that Memphis began to develop into a major American city- bonds were issued to finance civic improvements, public schools were instituted, and Memphis and South Memphis merged as one. The completion of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad in 1857 cemented Memphis’ status as the main commercial center along the central Mississippi River, and immigrants flocked to the boomtown. Much of the development that followed was in the nationally popular Italianate style.

The use of Italianate architecture announced Memphis’ arrival as an economic powerhouse, and the cosmopolitan nature that came with newfound wealth and prosperity. It also differed from the expression of antebellum economic prosperity favored by their rural neighbors: “Where plantation-style homes were built by the prosperous citizens of the county [Shelby], the aristocracy of Memphis was built on commerce, railroads and land speculation rather than on an agrarian tradition. Therefore, when the cotton factors and wholesale grocers who made up the top of Memphis society built their houses, they chose showy French and Italianate Victorian… rather than the more restrained Greek Revival style chosen by their neighbors in the county and in north Mississippi” (Magnus 10-11).

title: Gothic Revival / Commercial Gothic (1840-1940)
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)
 

The Gothic Revival architectural style was popular throughout the United States from the 1840s to the 1880s residentially, and on Church and university buildings through 1940. The style can be identified by steeply pitched, cross-gabled roofs, highly decorated vergeboards along the gables, and pointed-arch, or Gothic arch, windows that extend into the gables. Elements are commonly styled with flattened or full Gothic arches, trefoil and quatrefoil designs, tracery, and in some instances, castellated parapet walls. 

A part of the Picturesque/Romantic Movement, the Gothic Revival looked back to medieval Europe instead of ancient Greece and Rome. The asymmetrical floorplans of the residential Gothic forms complemented a building’s natural setting, while more symmetrical, high-style designs were found on churches. After Memphis rebounded from the Civil War and multiple Yellow Fever epidemics, the 1880s and 1890s again brought economic prosperity to the Bluff City. Improved transportation made granite and limestone and other imported masonry more accessible, and many religious buildings reflected the nationally popular Gothic Revival style of the time.

Early 20thcentury Memphis also saw a rise in the construction of the Commercial Gothicstyle. Commercial Gothic combined the basic structure of a commercial building with Gothic arches and tracery expressed in terra cotta instead of stone. The use of terra cotta made the ornamentation more affordable to reproduce and decorate the large façade of a skyscraper. Perhaps the most famous Commercial Gothic structure is the Woolworth Building in New York City, which gained the nickname “The Cathedral of Commerce” for its combination of sacred and commercial influences. Commercial Gothic structures were largely built in New York, Chicago, Boston, and Philadelphia between 1910 and 1930. Memphis’ collection of Commercial Gothic skyscrapers, including the Lincoln American Tower and the Sterick Building, reflect its ambitions during the commercial boom of the 1920s.

title: Romanesque Revival (1870-1900)
desc:
The Romanesque Revival architectural style was popular throughout the United States from the 1870s to the early 1900s. The style can be identified by asymmetrical, monochromatic masonry façades that emphasize the Classical Roman arch, with dense masonry walls, rounded towers, and thick round arches over windows and entryways.

The Romanesque Revival was a modern resurgence of the medieval Romanesque architecture popular in Europe during the 11thand 12thcenturies, which was itself a revival of earlier classical Roman forms. The Romanesque Revival was promoted as the most appropriate architectural style to suit modern American life in the late 19thcentury. As opposed to the earlier Greek Revival that hid modern inventions and necessities behind classical forms and order, the Romanesque Revival embellished them. The style is mostly found on largescale public buildings due to its massive construction costs and labor requirements, but it became an almost universal style for public buildings during the era.

After Memphis rebounded from the Civil War and multiple Yellow Fever epidemics, the 1880s and 1890s again brought economic prosperity to the Bluff City. Improved transportation made granite and limestone and other imported masonry more accessible. Major investments were made in commercial and public facilities, and many reflected the nationally popular Romanesque Revival style of the time.

title: Beaux Arts (1890-1930)
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)

The Beaux Arts architectural style was popular throughout the United States from almost exactly 1893 to 1929, that is, the period between its exposure at the World’s Columbian Exposition and the Great Depression. The ornate style can be identified by a heavily decorated, symmetrical façade with classical detailing, including pediments and paired columns and pilasters. The heaviness and formality of the style that favored ancient motifs made it ubiquitous with cultural and government buildings at the turn of the century. 

Influenced by classical Roman and Greek forms, it was the style of choice for the “White City” at the 1893 World’s Columbian Exposition in Chicago, which introduced the aesthetic of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris to the American public. The pleasing symmetry and monumental grandeur of the “White City” influenced the City Beautiful movement, which pushed urban beautification efforts to increase civic virtue in overcrowded and impoverished cities across the country, Memphis included. The Board of Park Commissioners was created in 1900, establishing Riverside Park, Overton Park, and the Parkway System. Overton Park’s Brooks Museum of Art and the growing city’s most important public buildings, including the Shelby County Courthouse, Memphis Police Station, and Union Station, as well as the renovation of the Post Office, employed the Beaux Arts style, announcing Memphis’ economic comeback and cultural significance on the national stage.

title: Sullivanesque / Chicago 1890-1930
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)

 

Chicago Style architecture, often called Sullivanesque, is based on Chicago School architect Louis Sullivan’s designs for early American skyscrapers popular throughout the United States from 1890 to 1930. Sullivan believed “form follows function”, and used purposeful ornamentation to define the new steel-frame skyscrapers into three distinct parts that reflected their purpose: the ground floor with prominent windows and points of entry, the midsection with vertical piers and bands of windows reflecting uniform office space, and a highly ornamented cornice to top it off.

Sullivan’s ornamentation using elaborate geometric forms and curving lines was also distinct, often featured in terra cotta or plaster panels and along a wide, decorative cornice beneath deep, projecting eaves. Sullivan merged natural, organic forms with the innovative science and technology of a fast-pasted, dynamic urban era. He aimed to integrate ornamentation with the building design as a whole, not merely applied as an attractive afterthought.

Sullivan’s Chicago School designs featuring his characteristic ornamentation and tripartite form can be found on early skyscrapers across the country. After Memphis rebounded from the Civil War and multiple Yellow Fever epidemics, the 1880s and 1890s again brought economic prosperity to the Bluff City, and a few early skyscrapers. The first steel-frame skyscraper in town was built by the Continental Bank in 1895 (now the D.T. Porter Building), and the Goldsmith Department Store soon followed. Coined “Memphis’ Greatest Store”, the early department store was one of the first in the South, and after humble beginnings, the flourishing business established its modern and innovative storefront on Main Street in 1895, choosing the modern Sullivanesque style to make its debut.

title: Italian Renaissance Revival (1890-1940)
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)
 

The Italian Renaissance Revival architectural style was popular throughout the United States from the 1890s to 1940. On residential structures, the style can be identified by a low-pitched, often tiled roof with wide overhanging eaves and decorative brackets. Classical arches frame doors and windows, and classical columns or pediments frame the entryway. 

Renaissance Revival architecture looks back to the Italian Renaissance period of the 1400s and 1500s, which itself was a revival of interest in ancient Greek and Roman art and culture. The Renaissance Revival was more ornate than the classicism of the original, and less restrained in its use of embellishments. The full essence of the Renaissance palazzos of Italy is best demonstrated on early commercial buildings and skyscrapers, where the style is identified by its massive scale and masonry construction, usually with a rusticated stone first floor and horizontal masonry bands separating subsequent floors. The invention of steel-frame construction methods and advances in masonry veneering techniques coincided with the style, and the imposing arched entrances and windows coupled with classical details, such as columns, arches, and balustrades became associated with the prosperity and industrialism of the turn of the century.

According to its National Register listing, Memphis’ most famous Italian Renaissance Revival building, the Peabody Hotel, was considered the “symbolic center of the social, cultural, and commercial life of the Mid-South region. Completed in 1925, it was the largest and most elegant hotel in the south and represents the area's finest example of the opulence, grandeur, and complexity which characterized the era of the grand hotel.”

title: Commercial Vernacular
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)
 

Very few buildings fit neatly into one architectural style. Many structures are influenced by multiple established styles, or none at all. Following National Register of Historic Places recommendations, commercial buildings that do not exhibit any one particular style can be labeled Commercial Vernacular.

Most buildings in Downtown Memphis are Commercial Vernacular in design. While vernacular buildings may reveal some influence by formal schools of design, vernacular architecture is designed based on local needs, function, materials, climate, and culture. Despite the functional nature of the Vernacular style, architecture of this type is not lacking in subtle ornamentation. Columns, arches, balustrades, or other details echo many of the classic features found in other popular styles of the day. And, many structures were built with personal touches such as year built, the building’s original owner or business, chiseled onto a pediment or cornerstone.

title: Hollywood Baroque Revival
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)


Originally built as the Pantages Theatre in 1921, the architecture of the now demolished Warner Theatre could best be described as HollywoodBaroque Revival. Many early twentieth century American theaters were built using Exotic Revival styles with over-the-top ornamentation. The terra cotta façade of the Warner features elements of the Baroque of 17thand 18thcentury Europe, which used contrast, movement, and vibrant detail in art and architecture. The ornate movement was the Catholic Church’s counter to the minimalism of the Protestant Reformation. The repeated use of architectural elements across the façade of the Warner, including the use of the cartouche, as well as a combination of concave and convex forms that give the façade a sense of motion, identify it as Baroque Revival. It was a fitting style choice for many theaters at the time, as the Baroque period was considered a golden age of theater in Spain and France.

title: Art Deco (1925-1945)
desc:
story(back to architecture,architecture)

The Art Deco architectural style was popular throughout the United States from 1925 to 1940. The style can be identified by sleek, sharp lines that create a series of setbacks or steps, and geometric ornamentation, such as chevrons or zigzags.

Instead of looking back to the past for inspiration, as other popular architectural styles of the day (Gothic Revival,Romanesque Revival,Beaux Arts,Italian Renaissance Revival, etc.) Art Deco looked to the future and fully embraced the modern Machine Age. Art Deco buildings utilized new construction technologies and materials, such as chrome plating, plastic, and stainless steel, and were finished with smooth materials, like stucco, glazed brick, concrete block, or mosaic tile.

The Art Deco movement was coined at the International Exhibition of Modern Decorative & Industrial Arts held in Paris in 1925. The early style represented luxury and glamour and the hope of technological and social progress. Memphis’ Sears Crosstown was constructed in this early version of the style in 1927, just as many other Sears warehouses and stores of the era nationwide. The architecture embodied exactly what Sears wanted to express to its customers- accessible luxury in the modern age. 

During the Great Depression of the 1930s, the style became more subdued and streamlined, often called Streamline Moderne, featuring simpler and more curved, polished surfaces. The Works Progress Administration designed many Art Deco style buildings during this era, including Memphis’ own Levitt Shell in Overton Park and the Gaston Park Community Center.

title: Art Deco (1925-1945)
desc:
The Art Deco architectural style was popular throughout the United States from 1925 to 1940. The style can be identified by sleek, sharp lines that create a series of setbacks or steps, and geometric ornamentation, such as chevrons or zigzags.

Instead of looking back to the past for inspiration, as other popular architectural styles of the day (Gothic Revival,Romanesque Revival,Beaux Arts,Italian Renaissance Revival, etc.) Art Deco looked to the future and fully embraced the modern Machine Age. Art Deco buildings utilized new construction technologies and materials, such as chrome plating, plastic, and stainless steel, and were finished with smooth materials, like stucco, glazed brick, concrete block, or mosaic tile.

The Art Deco movement was coined at the International Exhibition of Modern Decorative & Industrial Arts held in Paris in 1925. The early style represented luxury and glamour and the hope of technological and social progress. Memphis’ Sears Crosstown was constructed in this early version of the style in 1927, just as many other Sears warehouses and stores of the era nationwide. The architecture embodied exactly what Sears wanted to express to its customers- accessible luxury in the modern age. 

During the Great Depression of the 1930s, the style became more subdued and streamlined, often called Streamline Moderne, featuring simpler and more curved, polished surfaces. The Works Progress Administration designed many Art Deco style buildings during this era, including Memphis’ own Levitt Shell in Overton Park and the Gaston Park Community Center.

title: Mid-Century Modern (1935-1975)
desc:
The Mid-Century Modern architectural style, which is really an expansive movement that encompasses many styles of Modernism in art and architecture, was popular throughout the United States from the late 1930s to the 1970s. The most popular forms of Mid-Century Modern are most closely associated with the architecture built between the mid-1950s through the early 1960s. Residentially, the style can be identified by a flat or low-pitched roof, overhanging eaves, and an asymmetrical façade with off-centered entry and a mix of natural materials and modern building technologies. Designs aimed to bring the outdoors in using large expanses of windows and a modern, open floor plan, thanks to post and beam design that replaced bulky support walls with plate glass.

Asymmetry, angular details, and clean lines also characterized commercial architecture in the Mid-Century Modern style. Inspired by the International and Bauhaus architectural movements, form followed function in Modern design, and buildings reflected their purpose in their form and massing. New building materials like colored aluminum and panelized imitation stone, concrete or veneer panels, were combined with textured blond brick laid in decorative patterns, and modern forms of terra cotta ornamentation. New plate glass technologies and steel lintels and curtain walls allowed storefronts to be more visually opened to the street, and elevated roof lines and dramatic angles drew customers inward and projected a fresh, post-war aesthetic. 

In the booming post-WWII economy, businesses nationwide built modern storefronts in new suburban shopping centers or updated their old storefronts in the contemporary aesthetic, affirming their post-war relevance and efficiency.  This trend was enthusiastically embraced by Memphis businesses and architects, as the city sprawled out to the suburbs thanks to the new interstate highway system and urban renewal programs that wiped out huge sections of the urban core. Industrial parks, schools, government buildings, and shopping centers, like Poplar Plaza, were built in new modern styles on large expanses of land, now conveniently reached by automobile.  In order to compete, many downtown government and commercial buildings altered their façades, including the Cossitt Library on Front Street, and Goldsmith’s Department Store on South Main.

title: Britling Cafeteria
desc:
In the booming post-WWII economy, businesses nationwide built Mid-Century Modernstorefronts in new suburban shopping centers or updated their old storefronts in the contemporary aesthetic, affirming their post-war relevance and efficiency.  This trend was enthusiastically embraced by Memphis businesses and architects, as the city sprawled out to the suburbs thanks to the new interstate highway system and urban renewal programs that wiped out huge sections of the urban core. Industrial parks, schools, government buildings, and shopping centers, like Poplar Plaza, were built in new modern styles on large expanses of land, now conveniently reached by automobile.  

Traditionally, many businesses utilized the first-floors of multi-story buildings, with upper story windows bringing much needed natural light down to the first floor. Mid-Century Modernarchitecture utilized plate glass and curtain wall technologies paired with innovative lighting systems to dramatically open up the storefronts to the street, rendering the upper stories unnecessary. Upper windows could now be covered, like those at the Goldsmith’s Department Storeon Main Street, and modernized with glass, aluminum, or porcelain panels. If daylight was still needed, windows were often clad with open-weave aluminum panels instead. These metal grills became an elegant characteristic of the Mid-Century Modernaesthetic, and were often used in new construction, including on the Britling Cafeteria building in Poplar Plaza. Developed in the late 1940s, Poplar Plaza was one of the first suburban shopping centers in the nation. The Britling Cafeteria chain had two thriving locations in downtown Memphis, and opened another branch in Poplar Plaza in the early 1950s, choosing a sleek, woven-metal grill as a backdrop for the signage of their modern, suburban location.

Coined “Memphis’ Greatest Store”, Goldsmith’s Department Store was one of the first in the South, and after humble beginnings, the flourishing business established its modern storefront on Main Street in 1895, choosing the modern story(Chicago or Sullivanesque,chicagoStory)style to make its debut. In 1957, local Modern architect William Noland Van Powell covered the original ornate façade in sleek, pink marble panels to match the competing story(Mid-Century Modern,midcenturyStory) suburban commercial centers. The marble panels were removed in the early 1990s, revealing the preserved the original Sullivanesque façade beneath.

title: Commercial Appeal / Welcome Wagon Building
desc:
Influenced by classical Roman and Greek forms, the pleasing symmetry and monumental grandeur of the Beaux Arts architectural style influenced Memphis’ most important public buildings at the turn of the twentieth century, including the Shelby County Courthouse, Memphis Police Station, and Union Station, as well as the renovation of the Post Office. The style announced Memphis’ economic comeback and cultural significance on the national stage after surviving both the Civil War and multiple Yellow Fever epidemics. 

The style was also employed on many commercial buildings, including the original Commercial Appeal Building, later the Welcome Wagon Building, on Court Square. Built in 1907 by local architects Shaw & Pfeil, who also built the Beaux Arts Tennessee Trust Building (now Hu. Hotel) in 1904, the building has a distinctive rusticated first floor and an abundance of classical ornamentation, from a front-facing pair of two-story Ionic columns to the cast-stone ornaments along the cornice.

fold(More Information) fs()The Overton Park Orchestra Shell was built by the Works Progress Administration (WPA) in partnership with the City of Memphis in 1936. Because Overton Park, like other Memphis parks, was segregated until the 1960s, the Shell originally served white Memphians.  Among this group, the outdoor amphitheater was massively popular from the start, far exceeding its 4,000-person seating capacity on its first night.  

Throughout the 1930 and 1940s, the Memphis Open Air Theater (MOAT) and the Memphis Federation of Musicians staged musicals, operas, and operettas at the Shell.  During the 1950s through 70s, the Shell also hosted numerous major artists and cemented its notable place in music history.  In one of the most famous examples, the Shell served as the venue for Elvis Presley’s first paid performance as the opening act for Slim Whitman in 1954, and this breakout performance has since been known as the first rock and roll concert.  Other notable performers included Johnny Cash, Furry Lewis, Grateful Dead, the Allman Brothers, Seals & Croft.  Additionally, in 1966, the Shell hosted its first Country Blues Festival, which was one of the first integrated blues festivals in the United States.  

As it aged and Memphians’ entertainment patterns changed, Shell began grappling with dwindling popularity and deteriorating facilities.   By the mid-1960s, even while it was making music history, the Shell was slated for demolition to be replaced by a performing arts building.   However, Noel Gilbert, long-time conductor of the Memphis Concert Orchestra, successfully organized citizens in a campaign opposing its destruction.

In 1982, the National Conference of Christians and Jews and allied local groups successfully lobbied to rename the site the Raoul Wallenberg Shell in honor ofa Swedish diplomat who saved the lives of 15,000 Jews during the Holocaust.  The Shell was seen as an appropriate memorial for Wallenberg because it was a place for bringing people together.

Despite citizen efforts and its new name,without renovations, the Shell fell into disuse by the mid-1980s and was once again at risk of demolition.  Imminent destruction was held off by the use of the facility for the Arts in the Park Festival at Overton Park, which was revived during this period.  The festival included dance performances, displays from local artists, and exhibits from the Memphis College of Art and the Brooks Museum.

After the Arts in the Park festival of 1984, Mayor Dick Hackett announced that he would support renovating the Shell if a private group would establish an arts program there. This promise inspired Memphis local John Hanrahan to form Save Our Shell (SOS), an activist group dedicated to renovating the Shell and organizing events to celebrate its 50thanniversary. After his sudden death in 1986, Hanrahan’s family and friends continued organizing on his behalf. 

In 1987, SOS received $15,000 from the City Council to build handicapped bathrooms, pave a parking lot for performers, and establish an office phone. SOS was also successful in planning a wide array of summer performances, including jazz, pop, and classical music concerts.  The Shell operated under the auspices of SOS for the next eighteen years.  

Despite the efforts and successes of SOS and allied organizations, funding for needed renovations remained elusive.  The Overton Park Shell lay dormant beginning in 2004 after an engineering inspection commissioned by Park Services found hazardous conditions that rendered the Shell unusable. Although neither SOS nor the City had the money to renovate the Shell, the Mortimer and Mimi Levitt Foundation became interested in the Shell that same year. 

In 2005, the City and the newly-formed Friends of Levitt Pavilion Memphis (aka Levitt Shell) developed a partnership with the Levitt Foundation to renovate the structure.  Photographer Gary Walpole captured Shell in a moment before major change with his 2006 photograph.  The $1.3 million renovations began in 2007.

The newly christened Levitt Shell opened in August 2008 with a mission to build community through free music.  The Shell has since offered free summer concerts, along with a range of interactive shows.fe()

Date added to the National Register:  1979

Forces that led to change:  Natural deterioration, city funding priorities, cultural change, citizen activism (Save Our Shell)

title: About the Overton Park Shell
desc:
The Overton Park Shell was built by the Works Progress Administration (WPA) in 1936 to provide a venue for outdoor entertainment. This was one of 27 band shells built by the WPA.  The outdoor amphitheater was massively popular from the start, exceeding its 4,000-person seat capacity by 2,000 on its first night. Throughout the 1930s and 1940s, the Memphis Open Air Theater (MOAT) and the Memphis Federation of Musicians put on musicals and other programs at the Shell. During this time period, the MOAT served as the main source of entertainment programming at the Shell. 

Beginning in the late 1940s, however, the Shell began grappling with dwindling popularity and deteriorating facilities.  By the mid-1960s, the Shell had been slated for demolition to be replaced by a performing arts building, but the Memphis Opera Theater (MOT) revived interest in the Shell by putting on a trial of summer concerts.  This renewed interest in free summer concerts sustained the Shell for another twenty years. Rock artists became a staple at the Shell in the 1970s.

In 1982, the National Conference of Christians and Jews (NCCJ) tried to pool funds for Shell restoration, but their efforts were unsuccessful. Their endeavor resulted in the Shell being renamed the Raoul Wallenberg Shell in honor of the Swedish diplomat who aided Jews during the Holocaust. Without renovations, however, the Shell fell into disuse by the mid-1980s and was once again at risk of demolition.

Citizens responded strongly to the abandonment of the Shell. From 1984 to 1985, The Commercial Appealprinted a series of letters opposing the demolition of the Shell, with one suggesting that the Shell be renovated in time for its 50thanniversary the following year. After the Arts in the Park festival of 1984, Mayor Dick Hackett announced that he would support renovating the Shell if a private group would establish an arts program. This promise inspired Memphis local John Hanrahan to form Save Our Shell (SOS), an activist group dedicated to renovating the Shell and organizing events to celebrate its 50thanniversary. After his sudden death in 1986, Hanrahan’s family and friends continued organizing on his behalf. The Shell operated under the auspices of SOS for the next eighteen years. In 1987, the group received $15,000 from the City Council to build handicapped bathrooms, pave a parking lot for performers, and establish an office phone. SOS were also successful in planning a wide array of summer performances, including jazz, pop, and classical music concerts.

In 2004, however, an engineering inspection commissioned by Park Services found hazardous conditions that rendered the Shell inhospitable. The report concluded that repairs would cost $500,000, while removing the Shell would only cost $50,000. Although neither SOS nor the City had the money to renovate the Shell, the Mortimer and Levitt Foundation, a California-based organization dedicated to improving old band shells, became interested in the Shell that same year. In 2005, the City and the Friends of Levitt Shell began a $1.3 million renovation of the Shell.

The newly christened Levitt Shell opened in August 2008 to its signature summer concert series, highlighting performances of R&B, gospel, Americana, jazz, Latin music, and children’s shows. Today the Shell continues to offer free summer concerts, along with a range of interactive shows.

title: Peabody Hotel
desc:
The original Peabody Hotel opened in 1869.  A new building opened at its present location in 1925.  Throughout its history, it has been widely known as “the South’s grand hotel.”  It became the social and business hub of Memphis. Ducks have been a regular feature in the hotel’s lobby fountain since their introduction in a 1933 prank.  Beginning in 1937 the music of the Peabody’s bands was broadcast nationwide on CBS radio.  In its prime, the hotel’s lower two floors contained 40 retail shops and offices, as well as the headquarters of the Chamber of Commerce and the Rotary, Kiwanis, and Civitan clubs.

The Peabody was filled to capacity during the World War II period.  In fact, it was forced to implement a maximum stay of three days.  However, the hotel began to decline during the 1950s due to a variety of factors, such as suburbanization, the rise of chain hotels, desegregation, and the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  The hotel was sold multiple times between the 1950s and 1970s.  For a time, it was actually known as the Peabody-Sheraton.  

The Peabody was purchased at auction by Belz Enterprises in 1975.  Belz Enterprises held the mortgage for the hotel at the time of the auction, so the purchase was at least in part financially motivated.  However, the Belz Family, which owns Belz enterprises, also had a deeply personal connection to The Peabody Hotel.  In one example, among many important family celebrations, Jack Belz was married at The Peabody in 1948.  

Jack Belz had a strong vision of The Peabody’s potential.  He felt that if the restoration was done on a grand scale, the hotel would have the power to pull the entire downtown area up.  The renovation restored early features of the hotel such as stained-glass panels and decorative medallions on ceilings that had been covered with acoustical tile.

Funding was a major challenge in the restoration effort.  It took over 5 years to set up a loan deal, and this led to public questions about the hotel’s future.  Ultimately, a solution was found in the development of a funding pool, and this model has provided an important blueprint for other endeavors.

After an extensive, multi-million-dollar restoration that brought The Peabody back to its former glory, it reopened in 1981. The reopening of The Peabody is considered to be a catalyst event for the renaissance of downtown Memphis.  

The Peabody was named the nation’s best historic hotel in the 2018 USA Today’s Readers’ Choice awards.

title: Sears Crosstown
desc:
booklet(,crosstownThen)booklet(,crosstownNow)
thennow

Address:  1350 Concourse Ave. 

Category:  story(Adaptively Reused,adaptive)

Architectural style:  story(Art Deco,artdecoStory)

Date Opened:  1927

Original Use: Catalogue center and retail store

Date added to the National Register:  2013

Date Reopened:  2017

Current Use:  Mixed-use "vertical urban village"

booklet(Newspaper Articles,crosstownArticles)

fold(More Information) fs()Sears Crosstown was built at the extreme eastern edge of Memphis.  It was one of the first Sears retail outlets in the South and only the fifth catalogue order fulfillment center in the country.   It was also the largest building in Memphis at that time.  The facility became an important social and economic fixture in Memphis.  It was a leading employer through the Depression and World War II.  It was also a top destination for shopping and socializing.  Sears Crosstown was so successful that in five additions were made to the building in 1965, growing it to over 1,500,000 square feet.

During the 1950s, Sears began opening locations in the suburbs, which ultimately diminished the importance of the Crosstown location.  The retail store closed in 1983 and the customer credit center and catalog merchandise distribution center in 1990.  The building was put up for sale and vacated in 1993.  This led to fears regarding the decline of the surrounding area, and other businesses in the area also closed during that time.

Beginning in 1999, several attempts were made to renovate and reuse Sears Crosstown. However, early attempts were aborted after failure to secure necessary funding.  The effort that ultimately succeeded began in 2010 when Todd Richardson and Christopher Miner established Crosstown Arts.  This organization led the effort to redevelop the Sears Crosstown building into a vibrant center piece of the neighborhood.  

During 2012, the founding partners for the Crosstown Concourse were announced.  These included the Church Health Center, Memphis Teacher Residency, Methodist Le Bonheur Healthcare, St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, and ALSAC/St. Jude, among other highly-regarded institutions.  After three years of fundraising, the partnership secured $200 million in financing from 30 different sources to redevelop the Sears Crosstown building. In 2013, the Center City Commission granted Crosstown a 20-year PILOT (payment-in-lieu-of taxes) deal. The City of Memphis also agreed to contribute $15 million for Crosstown redevelopment.

A groundbreaking celebration was held in February 2015, and the Crosstown Concourse officially opened in August 2017 as a “vertical urban village” containing residential, commercial, educational, healthcare, and arts facilities.  The Crosstown Concourse, as the Sears Crosstown building was renamed, was the largest historic adaptive reuse LEED Building Design and Construction Platinum project in the world.

As of the beginning of 2019, the Crosstown Concourse contains 13 restaurants, 6 retail stores, an art gallery, a charter high school, 3 medical/dental establishments, a variety of non-profits, and 270 apartments.

The Crosstown Concours has received numerous awards.  The structure was honored in 2017 by The Architectural Review magazine with a nomination to a shortlist of 15 structures worldwide for its significance in adaptive use and retrofit “in a world with a growing awareness of the environmental implications of building anew” and the “re-appropriation of disused infrastructure.”  In 2018, the National Trust for Historic Preservation awarded the Crosstown Concourse the extremely prestigious Richard H. Driehaus Foundation National Preservation Award.

fe()

Forces that led to change:

Suburbanization and changes in the retail industry were two important factors in the decline and closure of Sears Crosstown.

The efforts of a local organization – Crosstown Arts –  and the support of the surrounding community were instrumental in the redevelopment of the site.  The investment of private and public money and financial incentives like the PILOT were also necessary factors.

title: Tennessee Brewery
desc:
booklet(,breweryThen)booklet(,breweryNow)
19492019

Address:  495 Tennessee St.

Category:  story(Adaptively Reused,adaptive)

Original Architectural Style: story(Romanesque Revival,romanesqueStory)

Date Opened:  1885

Dated Added to the National Register: 1980

Date Closed:  1954

Date Reopened:  2017

Forces that led to change:  Competition and prices, downtown decline and revival, community involvement, “previtalization”

booklet(Newspaper Articles,breweryArticles)

fold(More Information) fs()The Tennessee Brewing Company produced Pilsener, Export, Tennessee Pale, Bavarian and Columbian Extra Pale, and Erlanger.  At one point the largest brewery in the South, the company had around 1,500 workers and produced 250,000 barrels per year before Prohibition shut down production.

In 1909, prohibition by the state limited local sales of beer, but continued exports allowed the Brewery to thrive. Nationwide prohibition during the 1920s and 1930s, however, temporarily halted operations at the Brewery. The Brewery resumed production in 1933, and it became best known for its production of Goldcrest 51 Beer, which became the largest selling beer in the South.  Increasing competition and rising costs of production ultimately strained the business and caused its closure in 1954.  From 1955 to 1981, the Brewery housed A. Karchmer and Son Scrap Metals.

In the early 1980s, the building came into the possession of Laurence M. Bloch and Alvin J. Lazarov, but the developers failed to renovate the building, and it fell into disuse. The dilapidated building caught the attention of the Memphis Fire Department in 1998, and the owners were sued for violation of an anti-neglect ordinance. The building sustained significant damage over the years, including roof damage, broken exterior masonry, and smashed windows. Environmental Court Judge Larry Potter ordered the owners to bring the Brewery up to code or risk demolition. The Brewery was saved in 1999 when Kevin Norman purchased the building and paid to get it up to code. Over the following decade, Norman tried and failed many times to redevelop the Brewery.

An attempt made in 2006 reveals the importance of community input in the reuse of old structures. A group of developers planned the Tennessee Brewery Mixed-use Condominium and Retail Project which proposed a 14-story modern-style addition to the Brewery and demolition of much of the existing square footage. Although the project garnered support from some members of the City Council and neighbors of the Brewery, it drew heated criticism from the surrounding community as well as the Landmarks Commission. Citizens and the Landmarks Commission expressed concern about the Brewery being de-listed from the National Register of Historic Places if the renovation clashed with the Brewery’s original Romanesque style. Residents and neighbors of the South Main Historic District formed Citizens to Save the Brewery in order to organize against the condo project. Ultimately, the redevelopment attempt failed due to the City Council’s rejection of the plan’s density variance increase. As a result, the Brewery remained vacant and undeveloped for the next eight years until another surge of citizen activism brought the Brewery back into public consciousness.

In April of 2014, Norman announced that the building would be demolished if he could not sell it. The next month, restauranteur Taylor Berger, commercial realtor Michael Tauer, and communication specialist Doug Carpenter financed Untapped, a six-week beer garden held at the Brewery to demonstrate its lucrative potential and encourage likely buyers. This pre-vitalization effort was a great success. It served over 20,000 people and attracted cell tower developer Billy Orgel as a buyer. In August of the same year, Orgel announced plans for a mixed-use complex with 148 residential units and 16,000 square feet of commercial and office space. Orgel continued to cultivate public interest in the brewery project by holding a “revival” of Untapped the following year.

This popularity persisted until 2017 when the Brewery Apartments opened and reached full occupancy within five months. The Tennessee Brewery is currently undergoing its second phase of construction.fe()

booklet(Articles,customsArticles)

fold(More Information) fs() Construction of the Front Street Post Office began in 1876 after Congress passed an act to build a customs house and court house in Memphis.  Built in an Italian villa style with two matching towers, the Customs House began operations in 1885.  In 1929, when the building became a post office, it was remodeled by architect James A. Wetmore in an Italian Renaissance Revival style.   During remodeling, it was greatly enlarged, both towers were removed, and additional wings were added at the north and south ends.  The entire building also received a new outer wall of granite.

From 1930 to 1963, the building served as the Customs House, a federal court house, and a U. S. Post Office location. In 1963, the federal courthouse closed and relocated.  The building operated as a post office until the University of Memphis acquired the building in 2007 and announced plans to transfer the Cecil C. Humphreys School of Law there.  Renovation of the Customs House began in 2008 and was completed by 2009.  Law classes resumed at the new law school in January 2010.

The renovation of the Customs House has been celebrated as an exemplary case of adaptive reuse.  The Gulf States Region of the American Institute of Architects called the project “a perfect example of successful adaptive reuse” due to its revitalization of the area and preservation of historical significance and architectural character.  The AIA honored developers the Honor Award in 2011.fe()

Date Opened:  1924

Original Use: Commercial

fold(More Information) fs()The Columbian Mutual Tower was built by the Columbian Mutual Insurance Company and its president, Lloyd T. Binford in 1924.  The building, which overlooks Court Square, was modeled after the Woolworth Building in New York.  The Columbian Mutual Tower was one of the first steel frame skyscraper built in Memphis and remains a distinctive feature in the Memphis skyline.  The International Order of Odd Fellows owned the land where the Columbian Mutual Tower was built and leased it to the Columbian Mutual company with the stipulation that the new building would include space for the headquarters of the organization.

The building’s historical significance is largely derived from the original occupant of the building’s top floor, Lloyd T. Binford.  Binford was both the president of Columbian Mutual, the building’s owner, and the head of the Memphis Censor Board.

In 1965, Lincoln American Life Insurance Company acquired the building when it merged with Columbian Mutual.  The building has been known as the Lincoln American Tower since that time.  Over the next two decades, the building underwent a period of decline, along with the rest of downtown Memphis.  It changed hands in the 1980s and was used to secure millions of dollars in debt.  By the early 1990s, the buildings’ owners were no longer able to pay taxes or MLGW bills. The building changed hands again in 1992.  By that point, there were only 5 tenants left in the building, and plans for renovation and rejuvenation fell through.

Along with two neighboring buildings, the Lincoln American Tower is now part of a mixed-used development containing retail, offices, and apartments.  The tower underwent a six-year refurbishing project starting in 2002, and despite a fire in 2006, is now open.  The first tenants moved into the building in 2008.fe()

Date reopened:  2008

Current Use:  Residential

Forces that led to change:  Suburbanization, downtown exodus, financial mismanagement, renewed interest in living downtown

fold(More Information) fs()The Wonder Bread Factory building was built in 1905 as the Memphis Bread Company. From 1915 to 1919, the building housed both the Memphis Bread and Aunt Mary’s Cake Company beginning in 1930, the Continental Baking Company, the owner of Wonder Bread, shared the building with the Memphis Bread. In 1933, Continental Baking was the sole resident of 400 Monroe Avenue. The building operated as a bakery from its construction in 1905 until it was bought by Flower Foods in 2013 following Hostess’s bankruptcy.

In 2017, the old Wonder Bread factory was included in Development Services Group’s plan to revitalize the Edge district. The developers have proposed transforming the factory into a mixed-use project with 286 upscale residential units and office space. The bakery itself was purchased by Orion Federal Credit Union for its headquarters. The proposal has been supported by the Downtown Parking Authority, the Center City Revenue Finance Corporation (CCRFC), and the Design Review Board. The project is expected to be completed by 2020..fe()

fold(More Information) fs() The Sterick Building, which first opened in 1930, is built on land owned by the descendants of Napolean Hill and leased to the owners for a period of 99 years.  The Sterick Building was named for its builders and first owners, R.E. Sterling and Wyatt Hedrick. When the 29-story building first opened, it was the tallest building in Memphis, an honor it retained until 1962.  At the time it was known as the “Queen of Memphis” and advertised to potential tenants as an “ultra-modern skyscraper.

At one point, the Sterick was fully occupied by a variety of well-known tenants: Chrysler, Winchester Arms, Pets Milk, and Union Pacific Railroad.  It also served as the headquarters for the Goodfellows.  It remained prosperous through the 1950s, and, in 1959, the building’s owners branded it as a “city within a city.”  In 1963, and adjacent garage was added to the building.  This garage is particularly notable in architecture history because a hotel was built above it using a new type of concrete beam.

Like much of downtown in the late 1960s, the Sterick Building began to decline as tenants moved out. For the better part of two decades, the building fell into disrepair.  Tenants demanded modernization and maintenance from landlords, even bringing the issue to court.

There were significant exterior renovations to the building in the 1970s and again in the early 1980s. The Sterick Building was originally white, but it was painted gold during a 1982 renovation, which resulted in, at best, mixed reviews.

The building changed hands multiple times in the 1970s and 1980s, with subsequent owners promising renovations and modernization.  However, none of these efforts were ultimately successful.

The Sterick Building has been empty since 1987.  Although the Memphis Center City Commission placed the Sterick Building on its list of "Top Ten Center City Redevelopment Sites in 2006, there are no current plans to renovate or reopen the building.  Some of the issues that prevent the upgrade of the building include the vast size of the building, the floor plate’s height, inadequate duct work, asbestos removal, and seismic code requirements. title: About the Sterick Building
desc:
The Sterick Building, which first opened in 1930, is built on land owned by the descendants of Napolean Hill and leased to the owners for a period of 99 years.  The Sterick Building was named for its builders and first owners, R.E. Sterling and Wyatt Hedrick. When the 29-story building first opened, it was the tallest building in Memphis, an honor it retained until 1962.  At the time it was known as the “Queen of Memphis” and advertised to potential tenants as an “ultra-modern skyscraper.”  

At one point, the Sterick was fully occupied by a variety of well-known tenants: Chrysler, Winchester Arms, Pets Milk, and Union Pacific Railroad.  It also served as the headquarters for the Goodfellows.  It remained prosperous through the 1950s, and, in 1959, the building’s owners branded it as a “city within a city.”  In 1963, and adjacent garage was added to the building.  This garage is particularly notable in architecture history because a hotel was built above it using a new type of concrete beam.

Like much of downtown in the late 1960s, the Sterick Building began to decline as tenants moved out. For the better part of two decades, the building fell into disrepair.  Tenants demanded modernization and maintenance from landlords, even bringing the issue to court.

There were significant exterior renovations to the building in the 1970s and again in the early 1980s. The Sterick Building was originally white, but it was painted gold during a 1982 renovation, which resulted in, at best, mixed reviews.  

The building changed hands multiple times in the 1970s and 1980s, with subsequent owners promising renovations and modernization.  However, none of these efforts were ultimately successful.

The Sterick Building has been empty since 1987.  Although the Memphis Center City Commission placed the Sterick Building on its list of "Top Ten Center City Redevelopment Sites in 2006, there are no current plans to renovate or reopen the building.  Some of the issues that prevent the upgrade of the building include the vast size of the building, the floor plate’s height, inadequate duct work, asbestos removal, and seismic code requirements. Additionally, the Grosvenor family, which is descended from Napolean Hill, will take possession of the building after the 99-year land lease expires in 2025.  This timeframe makes it impossible for any outside developer to realize a sufficient return on renovating the building.

fold(More information) fs()The Coliseum was the first auditorium in Memphis planned as an integrated facility and the first major structure in the region built without segregated entrances or bathrooms. Performances before integrated audiences began as soon as the Coliseum opened.

The Coliseum is well known for hosting nationally and internationally prominent performers, including the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, The Who, Led Zeppelin, and Elvis, among others. Locally, it was central to the WDIA/Stax era of Memphis music history, as it hosted the WDIA Soul Review and numerous performances by Stax artists.

The Coliseum remained successful and popular through the 1970s and 80s.  In the mid-1980s, there was even discussion of expanding the Coliseum, although these plans were never carried through.  Ultimately, the City and County built a new arena, the Memphis Pyramid, downtown, and this facility opened in 1991.  It is around that time that the Coliseum entered a period of decline.

Two major issues ultimately led to the closure of the Coliseum after the 2006 season. The Coliseum was operating at a loss at that time, and Shelby County refused to pay its 40% share of funding after 2006.  At that point, Memphis also made the decision to stop funding and to close the building. Additionally, the City of Memphis had been sued for operating several buildings, including the Coliseum, that were not ADA compliant.  The federal government ordered the City to either bring these buildings into ADA compliance or cease operating them.  In the case of the Coliseum, the city chose to close the building rather than make the needed renovations.

In 2010, a group known as Save the Coliseum formed and facilitated the initial dialogue between concerned citizens and the City of Memphis.  In 2015, the City of Memphis began to actively pursue funding to redevelop the Mid-South Fairgrounds, and this was to include funds to demolish the Coliseum.  This specific effort to raze the Coliseum spurred the development of the Coliseum Coalition, which drew together a variety of individuals and organizations with an interest in saving the building.

The immediate goal of Save the Coliseum and the Coliseum Coalition was to prevent the demolition of the Coliseum. This goal was achieved in 2017, when the City agreed to “moth ball” the building.  The preservation of the Coliseum was confirmed in November 2018 when the State Building Commission approved the City of Memphis’ Tourism Development Zone (TDZ) application for the redevelopment of the Fairgrounds as a Youth Sports Complex.  A TDZ is a funding program for tourism attractions in a specific "zone" for which a baseline tax revenue is determined.  Once a TDZ is enacted, the increase in the tax revenue from the new / improved tourist attractions is able to be used to pay for the debt incurred to build the attractions.  The application that was ultimately approved, explicitly states, “The Mid-South Coliseum and other historic buildings are preserved rather than demolished.”

Save the Coliseum and the Coliseum Coalition have also brought the larger public to the Coliseum. In order to raise public interest in and excitement about the Coliseum, Save the Coliseum and the Coliseum Coalition has put on a series of annual “previtalization” events called Roundhouse Revival.  Previtalization is the temporary activation of an inactive or underutilized space. This is a tactic that has been highly successful at other Memphis sites, including the Crosstown Concourse and the Tennessee Brewery. Since 2015, thousands of Memphians have attended the annual Roundhouse Revival (4,500 people attended the first event), on the grounds outside of the Coliseum.  These events feature the three core “brands” of the Coliseum: music, wrestling, and basketball.fe()

Forces that led to change:  competition, need for upgrades, city and county decision making, citizen activism (Coliseum Coalition)

fold(More Information) fs()

Memphis’ first public library, the Cossitt Library, opened in 1893.  In addition to housing Memphis’ first library, the Cossitt also housed the city’s first museum.  

The Cossitt Library is named for businessman Frederick H. Cossitt, who experienced great success and hospitality in Memphis and wanted to give back to the city by building a library. Although he died before this project was realized, Cossitt’s daughters donated the funds used to build the library. 

During its first 25 years, the Cossitt Library became a major landmark and the most photographed building in the city, appearing on more postcards than any other landmark.  However, the library soon began running out of space for its collection andbegan the rather new concept of renting space around town and opening branches. 

In an effort to address the need for additional space, the library underwent a major renovation in 1924-25. This addition consisted of a rear addition designed in the building’s original style, which more than doubled the size of the library.   

The building underwent a second “renovation” in 1958, in attempt to expand, stabilize, and modernize the library. This renovation resulted in the destruction of the historic Romanesque façade and the creation of two connected buildings with distinctly different styles.

The Cossitt Library was segregated from its inception and remained so into the 1960s.  In fact, a group of Lemoyne-Owen students staged a sit-in there during the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s.

The fate of the Cossitt Library, even in its altered status, has been in doubt for many years.  The building is 80,000, but only 5,000 is currently open to the public.

In October 2016, a group of Memphians applied and received a $5 million grant to participate in "Reimagining the Civic Commons," a three-year demonstration project to help the city and greater community reconnect to the thing Memphis was built on: the Mississippi River.  $3 million of this grant is funding the renovation and reimaging of the Cossitt Library to serve the needs of contemporary Memphians. It will be a space not only for traditional learning, but also a space where the community can grow together and explore different types of learning, be it through reading, the arts, music, discussion, or personal connection. Flexible furnishings and design will create a scalable space that can be transformed easily to suit many different events and programs, from large open spaces for dance classes, theater, and more, to smaller studio spaces and breakaway rooms for more intimate events.

South Main Street
desc:
Main Street developed as a result of booming railroad traffic in the early twentieth century. Manufacturing plants and distribution warehouses were drawn to South Main by the railway. Memphis’s geographic location positioned it to become a center for railroad traffic within the United States. With the construction of Union Station in 1912 and Central Station in 1914, South Main quickly transformed from a residential area to a booming business center. The vast majority of buildings along South Main were built between 1910 and 1925 as a result of this boom. As of the submission of the districts National Register Nomination in 1982, all but a few of the 105 buildings on South Main were constructed between 1900 and 1930.

The 1920s were truly roaring for South Main as the district enjoyed its economic peak. By 1929, eight restaurants and eleven hotels had sprung up between Central Station and The Orpheum. South Main also became the main distribution center for MGM, Paramount, Warner Brothers, 20th Century Fox, and other major film studios, which clustered along Second Street as part of “Film Row.”

Many prominent businesses cropped up on South Main, including Piggly Wiggly, Meyer Brothers Drug Company, Puck Brand Foods, United Warehouse, Memphis Brewing Company. These companies employed tens of thousands of people.

By the 1950s, however, diminishing railroad prominence in Memphis led to fewer customers and failing businesses on South Main. Union Station closed its doors on March 31, 1964, and the building itself was demolished in 1969 and transformed into a post office parking lot. Concurrent with the declining popularity of railroads, manufacturing in Memphis shifted from the city to eastern industrial parks, leaving large warehouses vacant and vulnerable to deterioration. The assassination of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. at the Lorraine Motel in 1968 and resulting civil unrest was the nail in the coffin for South Main. Even the Arcade Restaurant, which had operated 24 hours a day since its founding in 1919, closed. Blight engulfed the neglected area for the next twenty years.  Redevelopment of South Main began in 1982 when Robert McGowan and Annie Mahaffey purchased 418 S. Main St. as their home and art studio. Robert lobbied the city for improved infrastructure and much-needed code enforcement to preserve the historic buildings on South Main. He also led advocacy efforts to get the South Main Historic District listed in the National Register of Historic Places. Consequently, developers began renovating many buildings on South Main, transforming them into art galleries, boutiques, restaurants, and loft apartments.

Shortly after McGowan’s revitalization effort, redevelopment of Main Street began in earnest, and a public debate over the usage of full-sized buses on the Mid-America Mall quickly ensued, with many City Councilmembers, Mayor Hackett, the Downtown Neighborhood Association, and local citizens opposed to the idea for fear it would disturb the flow and feel of the Mall and surrounding residential area.

In 1989, the borders of the Downtown Neighborhood Association expanded to include South Main. In 1999, the Center City Commission selected Cooper Carry, Street-Works, Harold A. Dawson, and the Goodman Corps. to serve as consultants for the redevelopment of Main Street. Cooper Carry’s plan for racial, gender, and occupational diversity on Main earned them leadership position in the consulting team.

Between 1995 and 2003, South Main experience a massive renewal. The renovation of eight warehouses and commercial buildings transformed South Main from a defunct industrial district to a center for innovation in art, food, and lifestyle. Local artists who lived and worked in the old buildings on South Main were key to the district’s transformation.

From 2002-2003, South Main became the center of a number of public debates surrounding historic preservation, building demolitions, and redevelopment plans. Among them was the proposed demolition of four buildings on Main between Gayoso and Union, with the Landmarks Commission opposing demolition in favor of saving the Italianate architecture of 83 S. Main.

In 2003, the Omni Building, the first redevelopment project on Main, received a 16-year PILOT contingent on plans to transform it into three apartments and 3700 square feet of commercial space. That same year another project on Main, the W. T. Grant Building, received a 19-year PILOT to transform it into 15 apartments and 11,000 square feet of commercial space.

By 2014, South Main seemed to have fully embraced its new identity. According to South Main president Brian Douglas, “South Main has evolved. Some call us the South Main Historic District. Some call us the South Main Arts District. Some combine it as the South Main Historic Arts District. We say South Main is legendary now. It’s more of a destination. It’s not just one thing.”

Today, more than 2500 people live on South Main, drawn to the neighborhood’s charm, walkability, and proximity to Downtown amenities. It is home to dozens of shops, restaurants, and creative organizations, all locally owned and operated. South Main has kept true to its origins by being a neighborhood built by those committed to the community. However, revitalization of the district is a work-in-progress with more than $200 million in new projects underway.

Ironically, South Main was saved by the very neglect that had rendered the district uninhabitable for businesses in the late 60s. Because no developers were interested in South Main for two decades, its many architectural gems live on. Nearly a century after their construction, the buildings on South Main look much as they did in the early 1900s comprising a wide range of architectural craftsmanship, including strong Beaux Arts, Georgian Revival, and Chicago Commercial style influences. As Robert McGowan noted in 1986, South Main is a “uniquely intact stretch of small-scale period architecture.”

Beale Street was established during the first half of the nineteenth century. During the 1840s, Beale Street was lined with large homes for wealthy whites. In the years leading to the Civil War, Beale became a commercial district for free blacks. Beale became a hotbed for African American land ownership, entrepreneurship, and community activity with the establishment of several businesses, and Freedman’s Bank, and black churches after the Civil War. During Reconstruction, racist public accommodation policies further cemented lower Beale as a major commercial strip for black Memphians. The first half of the twentieth century saw Beale at its peak as it blended commercial spaces with entertainment venues and embraced ethnic minorities. Irish and Italian immigrants dominated ownership of businesses and saloons until the 1920s, when Jewish immigrants and African Americans also joined as property-owners. Greek and Chinese immigrants also found a home in the blended community on Beale Street.

The environment on Beale also lent itself to the advent of blues. Known as “the underworld” during its peak, Beale welcomed a mix of pawn shops, cafes, dance halls, and theaters. Blues became popularized during the early 1900s by W. C. Handy’s performances at Peewee’s Saloon. Other popular clubs included the Monarch Club, the Panama club, and Hammitt Ashford’s Saloon.

During the 1930s, Memphis police began their crackdown on illicit activities, such as bootlegging and gambling, but Beale remained a popular entertainment district through the 1940s and 1950s, attracting musical talents like Elvis Presley, Sam Phillips, and B. B. King.

Beginning in the 1960s, however, Beale Street. began its long decline. As a target of contemporaneous urban renewal initiatives, Beale was slated for redevelopment as a suburban-inspired district. Federal funding was exhausted before redevelopment could fully begin. As a result, the forty blocks of Beale were reduced to just three. All businesses, with the sole exception of A Schwab, relocated or filed for bankruptcy. The remaining vacant buildings were boarded up and left exposed to vandals. The assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in 1968 hastened this process, as both peaceful protests and reactionary riots drove whites out of the city and steered the private sector eastward. Amidst all this change, Beale St. received its National Historic Landmark designation.

In 1969, Memphis Housing Authority (MHA), which signed an urban renewal contract in 1963, began clearing hundreds of Beale Street properties and nearby slum housing in an effort to transform the area into a major tourist destination. However, this type of urban renewal, which had already been discredited as a viable solution, further depleted Beale’s vitality. At the start of MHA’s project, 625 buildings stood on Beale Street. By 1979, only 69 remained, and over 1500 residents had been displaced. Officially, structural unsoundness was named as the primary catalyst for urban renewal, anecdotal evidence and racially coded language reveals that the desire to cater to white tourists also informed many of MHA’s decisions. The Housing Authority’s plan called for the hardware stores, liquor stores, beauty salons, and other businesses that would not appeal to tourists to be converted into nigh spots, restaurants, and curio shops. According to A. P. Johnson, the deputy director of MHA in the 1970s, MHA sought to build “an area that would not be subject to the type of crime prevalent in those areas. It was felt people just wouldn’t come to that type of area. For those reasons, the block immediately north and south of Beale were cleared.”

In 1973, after razing hundreds of homes and businesses, MHA sought bids from private companies to rebuild Beale Street.

In 1977, the Division of Housing and Community Development created the Beale Street Historic Restoration Project to oversee the revitalization of Beale. The project was to include new construction, restoration, and public improvements, which necessitated the collaboration of local, state, federal, and private entities. The Beale Street Development Corporation (BSDC), a nonprofit corporation, was tasked with finding funds, locating tenants, and encouraging minority participation. The for-profit Beale Street Properties, Ltd (BSP). was tasked with managing tenant leases and developing new structures. The city itself was responsible for retaining ownership of Beale and monitoring development through the newly formed Beale Street Steering Committee. Despite these clearly defined roles, the project faced many difficulties caused by in-fighting and restrictions on money usage. Developers also encountered initial difficulties in garnering private support for the project. The effort to restore Beale, however, inspired Congress to support a bill naming Beale St. as the official “home of the blues” in December 1977.

 By the early 1980s, redevelopment of Beale Street. was still in flux. In 1980, BSDC executive director George Miller temporarily resigned after it was rumored that he was involved with BSP. This incited a heated debate about the competency of BSDC leadership, the involvement of African Americans in the project, and the role of the media in exacerbating tensions. Meanwhile, the city refused to request any more state funding for Beale until reliable leadership in BSDC was ensured. In 1981, Miller was fired after an investigation concluded that Miller was indeed involved in both the BSDC and BSP.

In 1982, Elkington & Properties, a private non-profit corporation, was chosen by the city to serve as the management and development company for Beale, which greatly streamlined the redevelopment process. Phase I of redevelopment began in 1983. It included the development of 87,000 square feet of restaurant, entertainment, and retail space. Developers also succeeded in gaining private investments in Beale. Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola, Holiday Inn, Malone & Hyde, Plough Broadcasting Co., and Republic Airlines donated over $600,000 to the project. In March 1983, the new tenants of Beale were announced to include country blues singer Charlie Rich, Lou Rawls, and fifteen others of various ethnicities. The street reopened in September of the same year to much fanfare. Editorials praised it a symbol of racial unity and harmony.

Phase II of the Beale project, the redevelopment of an additional 100,000 square feet, commenced in 1985. However, the struggles of the previous year persisted. Although business tenants had been promised profit, many complained of increasing rent and expensive maintenance costs. Entertainers like Charlie Rich and Lou Rawls were supposed to supplement existing businesses with clubs of their own, but Rawls backed out, and Rich’s club was delayed. By February 1985, six businesses had closed, while the remaining tenants possessed a debt of $500,000. In contrast to tenant frustration, developers Elkington & Keltner remained optimistic about the future of Beale.

Elkington and Keltner also faced criticism from black leaders who worried that Beale’s historic integrity as a center of black life would not be preserved in the course of revitalization. At a meeting for the Beale Street Community Forum it was agreed that all plans for Beale should retain cultural and historical authenticity, and input from black leaders and community members was sought.

From 1986 to 1987, Beale Street faced the threat of losing its national register nomination due to the alteration and deterioration of too many structures. Ultimately, Beale’s landmark designation also became integral to the success of its redevelopment. Ten years after initial doubt about Beale’s historical integrity, the street was taken off the Park Service’s endangered list.

Today, Beale Street is both a popular tourist destination and a celebration of Memphis history.
